title: SAT Reading Fundamentals
description: Master the core concepts of SAT Reading comprehension - central ideas and supporting details
learningObjectives: Identify central ideas in complex passages
Distinguish between main ideas and supporting details
Apply systematic reading strategies to SAT passages
Avoid common traps in answer choices

content.title: Central Ideas & Evidence
content.subtitle: Big-picture understanding
content.text: In this lesson, you'll master the foundational skills that are essential for SAT Reading success. We'll focus on identifying central ideas and distinguishing them from supporting details.
keyPoints: Recognize the author's main claim or purpose
Select evidence that directly supports the main claim

content.title: Why It's Tricky
content.text: The most fundamental skill in SAT Reading is distinguishing between what the author's main point is versus the specific details they use to support that point. This sounds simple, but test makers deliberately create wrong answers that look appealing.
content.explanation: Answers look appealing because they lift words from the passage but distort scope or focus on a minor detail.
content.example: If the passage argues renewable energy is *promising but challenging*, a trap might claim it 'solves all climate problems' — too broad.

strategy.name: Topic Sentence Strategy
steps: Step 1: Ask after each paragraph — 'Why is the author telling me this?'
Step 2: Predict the main idea in 5–7 words before answer choices
Step 3: Eliminate answers that exaggerate or miss the scope
Step 4: Confirm the correct answer is supported in at least 2 places

trapAlerts: Too broad - answer choice expands beyond what the passage actually claims
Too narrow - answer choice focuses on one detail rather than the whole passage
Outside the text - answer choice brings in information not discussed in the passage

examples.passage: Scientists have recently discovered that urban gardens not only provide fresh produce for city residents but also help reduce air pollution and create habitats for beneficial insects. While these gardens require initial investment and ongoing maintenance, cities that have implemented community garden programs report improved neighborhood cohesion and reduced grocery costs for participants.
examples.question: The passage primarily argues that:
choices: A) Urban gardens completely solve food insecurity in cities
B) Community gardens provide multiple benefits despite requiring investment
C) Air pollution can only be reduced through urban gardening
D) Cities should eliminate traditional parks in favor of gardens
examples.explanation: Choice B captures the balanced claim about benefits and costs. A is too absolute ('completely solve'), C is too narrow (only focuses on air pollution), and D introduces information not in the passage.

content.title: Guided Practice
content.instructions: Let's practice with a real SAT-style question. Read the passage carefully and apply our 4-step strategy.

questions.passage: The resurgence of vinyl records in the digital age presents a fascinating paradox. Despite the convenience and portability of digital music, vinyl sales have grown consistently over the past decade. Music enthusiasts cite the 'warmth' of analog sound and the ritual of playing records as key attractions. However, this revival isn't merely nostalgic—younger generations, who never experienced vinyl's original era, now represent the largest segment of buyers. Record stores report that these new collectors appreciate both the tactile experience and the intentional listening that vinyl encourages, contrasting sharply with the background consumption typical of digital streaming.
questions.question: Which choice best identifies the central idea of the passage?
choices: A) Digital music has failed to satisfy serious music listeners
B) Vinyl records provide superior sound quality to all other formats
C) The vinyl revival reflects both nostalgic and new appreciation for intentional music experiences
D) Younger generations prefer outdated technology over modern innovations
hints: Look for the recurring theme across the entire passage
Notice how the passage discusses both older enthusiasts and younger buyers
Eliminate choices that are too absolute or miss key elements
questions.explanation: Choice C captures the passage's main point about the vinyl revival involving both traditional appreciation (older enthusiasts) and new motivations (younger buyers seeking intentional listening). A is too extreme ('failed'), B focuses on one detail (sound quality), and D mischaracterizes the younger generation's motivations.

content.title: Demonstrate Your Understanding
content.instructions: Complete these questions to demonstrate mastery of central ideas and supporting details. You need 75% accuracy to advance.

questions.passage: Recent studies in cognitive psychology suggest that multitasking, long praised as an efficiency skill, may actually hinder productivity and learning. Researchers found that people who frequently switch between tasks take longer to complete each individual task and make more errors. The brain, it appears, requires time to refocus when transitioning between different types of activities. However, not all task-switching is equally problematic. Simple, routine tasks can often be combined effectively, while complex cognitive work suffers significantly from interruption.
questions.question: The passage primarily serves to:
choices: A) Promote multitasking as an essential modern skill
B) Argue that all forms of task-switching reduce productivity
C) Present research challenging common assumptions about multitasking
D) Demonstrate that cognitive psychology lacks practical applications
questions.explanation: The passage presents research findings that challenge the conventional wisdom about multitasking being beneficial, while also noting nuances (some tasks can be combined). A contradicts the passage, B ignores the exception mentioned, and D is not supported by the text.

questions.passage: Marine biologists studying coral reef ecosystems have discovered that certain fish species serve as 'cleaners,' removing parasites from larger fish. This symbiotic relationship benefits both parties: the cleaner fish obtain food, while their clients receive health benefits. What's remarkable is that these cleaning stations operate on a form of 'trust'—predator fish that would normally eat the cleaners instead patiently wait to be serviced. Some researchers argue this behavior demonstrates basic economic principles in nature, including service quality, customer loyalty, and even 'cheating' when cleaners take bites of healthy tissue instead of just parasites.
questions.question: The main point of the passage is that:
choices: A) Cleaner fish have evolved to be immune to predator attacks
B) Coral reefs contain the most complex ecosystems on Earth
C) Fish cleaning relationships demonstrate economic-like behaviors in nature
D) Marine biology research focuses primarily on symbiotic relationships
questions.explanation: The passage describes cleaning relationships but emphasizes how they demonstrate economic principles in nature (trust, service quality, customer loyalty, cheating). A is not mentioned, B is too broad, and D mischaracterizes marine biology research focus.

content.title: Mastering Central Ideas
content.text: Congratulations! You've mastered the fundamental skill of identifying central ideas versus supporting details. This foundation will serve you well throughout your SAT preparation.
keyTakeaways: Central ideas capture the author's main claim or purpose across the entire passage
Supporting details provide evidence but aren't the main focus
Systematic strategies improve both accuracy and speed
Always predict before looking at answer choices
